headline.main: Study Suggests Shaken Faith Can Worsen Poor Health

docs.abstract: New study suggests some forms of religious anxiety may increase risk of death among people who are ill, and that religion and good health do not necessarily go hand in hand; researchers who surveyed elderly hospitalized patients found that those who wondered whether God had abandoned them or had similar doubts were more likely two years later to have died than other patients; patients were almost all Christian; Dr Kenneth I Pargament, Bowling Green University professor and lead author of study, comments (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Religion and good health go hand in hand. Or so some researchers have asserted in studies over the last half decade, saying that people who attend church regularly, pray or are otherwise involved in religious activities enjoy longer lives and other positive health benefits. But in a study published today, researchers contend that some forms of religious anxiety may in fact increase the risk of death among people who are ill.
